author: Hannah Wade hannahw@free-times.com
title: Groundbreaking: Scout Motors gets rolling on $2B electric vehicle plant in Blythewood
text:
BLYTHEWOOD — Officials broke ground at Scout Motors, a $2 billion electric vehicle plant poised to bring 4,000 new jobs to Richland County, on Feb. 15.
"We took a lot of looks around this great country, and the answer was quite clear. And that's why we're here in Blythewood, and that's why we're here in South Carolina," Scout's CEO Scott Keogh said.
While no hard hats were donned or shovels dug into the ground, state leaders and top representatives from Scout celebrated the kickoff of construction the morning of Feb. 15.
The project, set to take up 1,100 acres of the 1,600-acre Blythewood Industrial Site just off of Interstate 77, is the Midlands' largest economic development boon in recent years. The company estimates that construction on the site will require anywhere from 5,000 to 6,000 workers to see it to completion.
A separate exit will be added to I-77, paving a direct path to the plant from the busy interstate, officials announced Feb. 15. The new road will be named Scout Motors Drive. The hope is that the new road will deter traffic congestion on the existing Blythewood Road, which leads to the plant.
The groundbreaking ceremony comes a little over a month after crews were
given the go-ahead to continue clearing land at the site through a permit issued by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.
The EV plant is a part of a growing push by state officials to make South Carolina a leader in electric vehicle manufacturing.
When it announced in March of last year, Scout, a Volkswagen subsidiary, was the fifth auto plant to build electric vehicles in the state — joining Mercedes-Benz Vans, Volvo Cars and its Polestar subsidiary, and BMW. Battery manufacturers for those vehicles, like
China-based Envision AESC in Florence and e-Vac Magnetics in Sumter, are set to open in the coming years.
"It's hard to believe that a year ago a few of us were locked down in a closed-room session trying to figure out how we could be competitive for this Scout facility ... now, a year later, you look around and see all the work that's going on," state Secretary of Commerce Harry Lightsey said.
The small town of Blythewood in South Carolina's Midlands region beat out some 70 other locations competing for the plant.
The state pulled out all the stops to bring the company to Blythewood, including a state-record $1.3 billion incentive package and inviting the company's officials to a party at Williams-Brice Stadium, where the University of South Carolina Gamecocks play football. Part of those incentives include a child care credit for the company, which will mean workers at the plant receive free child care.

author: FOX 26 Digital
title: TEA investigates Fort Bend ISD for alleged electioneering, Open Meetings Act violations
text:
FORT BEND COUNTY, Texas - The Texas Education Agency (TEA) has launched an investigation into Fort Bend Independent School District (ISD) following electioneering complaints and violations of the Texas Open Meetings Act.
TEA is looking into allegations Fort Bend ISD incentivized students and staff to vote in last year's Voter Approval Tax Rate Election, which was successfully passed. The investigation is also scrutinizing claims that the district breached the Texas Open Meetings Act during employment decisions involving the district's former superintendent, Dr. Christi Whitbeck.
RELATED: Fort Bend ISD Superintendent Dr. Christie Whitbeck retires early amid controversy
Dr. Whitbeck's abrupt retirement last year sparked controversy, as it came only months after she received a new contract and a raise. The school board approved her retirement in a closed-door session, raising questions about the transparency of the process.
In response, Fort Bend ISD's new superintendent, Dr. Marc Smith, has issued a statement affirming the district's commitment to full cooperation with the TEA's investigation. "We are dedicated to being transparent and will provide all requested information."
"It is a new day in Fort Bend ISD with a new administration," said FBISD Board President Kristin Tassin. "Our board intends to work with Dr. Smith to ensure our district fully cooperates with the REA and is transparent with our community."
The investigation remains ongoing, and the district awaits further developments as the TEA continues its inquiry into these serious allegations.

author: @infobae
title: Ovejas de nariz negra de Valais, el tesoro suizo que conquista al mundo - Infobae
text:
Esta raza se caracteriza por tener la piel de color negro. (Wikimedia) Con un pelaje blanco como la nieve y piel de un negro tan profundo que contrasta a la perfección, las ovejas de nariz negra de Valais se convirtieron en una raza codiciada y apreciada por su apariencia única.
Son originarias de la región del Valais, Suiza , y es considerada como una raza de doble propósito, pues suele ser criada para obtención de su carne y lana. Debido a que es exclusiva de las zonas altas, éste animal se adaptó perfectamente a las condiciones adversas de la montaña, de acuerdo con especialistas de la Valais Black Nose Sheep Society (VBSS).
Dichas adaptaciones, además de ayudar a que tuvieran un gran éxito en su ambiente natural, las hizo un animal “extremadamente resistente, prolífico y frugal”, según los expertos de la organización que desde 2017 busca apoyar el desarrollo de la raza.
Una apariencia única Son apreciados por su apariencia. Existen reportes de las primeras menciones sobre esta curiosa variante de oveja durante el año 1.400 d.C, sin embargo, no fue sino hasta 1962 que se le reconoció como una raza separada.
Su característica piel negra que cubre nariz, ojos, orejas, rodillas, corvejones y patas contrasta enormemente con el blanco de su pelaje y las convierte en una raza inconfundible. A su estética se suman unos cuernos en forma helicoidal o espiral. Sin importar si son machos o hembras, las ovejas de nariz negra de Valais cuentan con esta curiosa cornamenta.
A su lista de cualidades se suma que son animales adaptados para pastar sin ningún tipo de problema en pendientes rocosas y empinadas, propias de la región en que fueron criados por primera vez.
Especialistas de la VBSS informaron que esta raza fue criada exclusivamente en Suiza durante muchos años hasta que fueron importados a las islas británicas durante 2013 y 2014.
Un par de años después, en otoño de 2016, comenzó su importación a Estados Unidos mediante un programa que utiliza el semen recolectado las ovejas de nariz negra de Valais de raza pura.
El estándar de la raza permitido por los miembros del club especifica que son animales dotados de un físico “robusto y de gran tamaño”, es necesario que su nariz esté centrada y se extienda hasta los ojos.
La coloración negra característica debe estar presente en tobillos y rodillas delanteras. En el caso de las hembras, estas deberán tener manchas de color oscuro en la cola.
El estándar de la raza Los corderos ya cuentan con el look característico de la raza desde que nacen. En cuanto a los cuernos, es necesario que estén equilibrados, mientras que sus patas necesitan demostrar un “crecimiento de lana uniforme”, así como estar bien cubiertas.
Como se mencionó anteriormente, son animales robustos y corpulentos, por lo que las hembras tienden a pesar entre 70 y 90 kilos, mientras que los machos suelen alcanzar los 80 y 125 kilos. Midiendo aproximadamente de 72 a 78 centímetros y de 75 a 83 centímetros, respectivamente.
El estándar de la raza solicitado por el VBSS especifica que las piernas deben ser “fuertes y bien colocadas”, al mismo tiempo que sus extremidades delanteras no deben estar abiertas o “valgas”.
La lana debe medir “aproximadamente” 10 centímetros, es decir, contar con un crecimiento de cinco a seis meses y deben esquilarse dos veces al año.
Su color debe ser “blanco y uniforme”, no obstante, los jueces que inspeccionan a los participantes de esta raza toleran la presencia de pelo negro “disperso” en el cuello.
Mandíbula condensada, dientes desalineados, enanismo o ruptura del saco testicular, así como una cantidad “excesiva” de pelaje de protección son consideradas como características indeseables durante los concursos de exhibición de las ovejas de nariz negra de Valais.

author: Angelo Amante
title: Italy's right-wing government faces backlash for celebrating WW2 fascists
text:
Brothers of Italy traces its roots to the Italian Social Movement, formed as a direct heir of Mussolini's blackshirts For free real time breaking news alerts sent straight to your inbox sign up to our breaking news emails Sign up to our free breaking news emails Please enter a valid email address Please enter a valid email address SIGN UP I would like to be emailed about offers, events and updates from The Independent. Read our privacy policy Thanks for signing up to the
Breaking News email {{ #verifyErrors }} {{ message }} {{ /verifyErrors }} {{ ^verifyErrors }} Something went wrong. Please try again later {{ /verifyErrors }}
Italy's right-wing government is facing criticism over its celebration of a major World War Two battle, after the defence ministry said the defeated fascist soldiers of dictator Benito Mussolini had died for the country's freedom.
In a social media post on Wednesday commemorating the anniversary of the 1942 battle of El Alamein in Egypt, the ministry described the conflict as "heroic and tragic" and paid homage to Italy's soldiers "who sacrificed their lives for our freedom."
The battle pitched the combined forces of fascist Italy and Nazi Germany, led by German General Erwin Rommel, against…
Angelo Amante

author: @type
title: Michigan agency's forum warns of election-year violence, hostility
text:
Speakers at a Thursday forum, organized by the Michigan Department of Civil Rights, cautioned about potential increases in hate crimes and threats tied to the 2024 presidential election. The two-hour event was part of the department's "MI Response to Hate Campaign," which aims to increase awareness about hate and bias.
Presenters from the the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights said hate crimes have been on the rise. At the same time, over the last four election cycles, hate crimes have tended to increase in election years as the politics become more divisive, they said.
"Broadly speaking, there is a parallel between the political climate and the number of reported hate crimes," said Nadia Aziz, senior director for the Fighting Hate and Bias Program at the Washington, D.C.-based Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights. "And we're, of course, concerned that the 2024 general election cycle will be no different from the previous cycles."
Social media companies have failed to curb hatred on their platforms, and the highly charged political climate has made it easier for "conspiracy theories and disinformation to spread like wildfire," said Carter Wynne, a program manager with the leadership conference.
In November, voters will pick a candidate to be the country's president for the next four years. President Joe Biden, a Democrat, and former President Donald Trump, a Republican, are their parties most likely nominees, meaning they could face off in a rematch of the 2020 race.
In 2020, Biden won Michigan by 3 percentage points or 154,000 votes. However, Trump maintained false claims that widespread fraud swayed the outcome , spurring protests and a push to overturn the result.
During Thursday's forum, Izabella Silva, clerk engagement organizer for central Michigan for the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan, cited 2023 survey data that showed about half of the election clerks said they had been insulted. In the same data, about 20% of the participating clerks said they had been threatened.
The Bridging Divides Initiative at Princeton University and CivicPulse tracked the numbers .
"The findings of this study highlight the need for collective action to address and mitigate some of the pressure that local officials and election administrators are facing as they work to carry out our elections," Silva said.
Oakland County Clerk Lisa Brown, a Democrat, also spoke at the Thursday forum, saying hostility was likely the biggest threat facing election workers in Michigan.
Brown noted the state Legislature passed a bill last year making it illegal to intimidate an election official or otherwise prevent election officials from performing their duties .
cmauger@detroitnews.com

author: The Daily News Sports Staff sports@tdn.com
title: Seven local teams set to play in MLK Classic on Monday
text:
Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Lower Columbia College Athletics will host the Diamond Showcase MLK Classic high school boys and girls basketball event on Martin Luther King Jr. Day , Monday. There will be eight games in total which will all be played at LCC’s Myklebust Gymnasium.
Quality journalism doesn't happen without your help Support local news coverage and the people who report it by subscribing to The Daily News.
Six Cowlitz County teams and Wahkiakum are set to play in the showcase. The Kalama girls will get things started against Battleground (4A) at 9:30 a.m. The Castle Rock boys will then face off against Toledo (2B) at 11 a.m., followed by Kelso and Hockinson (2A) girls at 12:30 p.m.
Next up we have two local teams battling it out when the Wahkiakum (1B) and Kalama (1A) boys battle it out at 2 p.m. The Mark Morris boys will look to take down another 3A opponent when they duel Evergreen at 6:30 p.m. Finally, the Kelso boys will play W.F. West (2A) in the final game of the day at 8 p.m.
People are also reading… Longview's new credit card fee goes into effect Longview man arrested in 1983 Iowa homicide cold case Hotel at Cowlitz County Event Center fell through in 2023. Here is where plans stand now. Longview restaurant to host sports simulator, from golf to baseball Cowlitz County Sheriff's Office searches for missing woman Longview staff to use ATVs, so council OKs vehicles for everyone 2025 season might be last for Cowlitz Black Bears in Longview Highlands shooter tells police he was protecting sister RA Long coach searches for possible 99th win at Civil War game Longview city manager finalists include parks and rec leader, St. Helens employee, more Police: Kelso man tries to light butane canister in home during arrest State and gun shop clash at WA Supreme Court over high-capacity magazine ban Family of 3 loses pet in Coal Creek fire Longview police: More arrests possible after Highlands shooting Local industrial boom drives concrete materials company's move to Kalama Tickets prices are $10 for adults and $7 for seniors and children for all-day entry. All proceeds will go to support LCC women’s basketball.
Stay up to date on Lower Columbia news, wherever you go Check out more coverage at x.com/DRosenfieldTDN .
